translated: Consciousness …

analyzed: cakkhu pe
translated: The eye …

original: jarāmaraṇaṁ aniccaṁ khayaṭṭhena, dukkhaṁ bhayaṭṭhena, anattā asārakaṭṭhenā”ti sotāvadhānaṁ, taṁpajānanā paññā sutamaye ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: jarā maraṇam aniccam khaya ṭṭhena dukkham bhaya ṭṭhena anattā asāraka ṭṭhena ati sota avadhāna tapa jānanā paññā suta maye ñāṇa
translated: Ageing-and-death is impermanent in the sense of destruction, painful in the sense of terror, not-self in the sense of having no core”: attention is applied thereto, that is knowledge of what consists in the heard.

analyzed: tam ñāta ṭṭhena pajānana ṭṭhena paññā
translated: That is knowledge in the sense of known, understanding in the sense of understanding.

analyzed: tena vuccati
translated: Hence it was said:

original: “sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā, sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā, sabbe dhammā anattā”ti sotāvadhānaṁ, taṁpajānanā paññā sutamaye ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: sabbe saṅkhārā aniccā sabbe saṅkhārā dukkhā sabbe dhammā anattā ati sotāvadhāna tapa jānanā paññā suta maye ñāṇa
translated: “All determinations are impermanent, all determinations are painful, all ideas are not self”: giving ear thus is understanding consisting in what is heard.

original: Kathaṁ “idaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ
analyzed: katham idam dukkham ariya sacca idam dukkha samudayam ariya sacca idam dukkha nirodha
translated: “This is the noble actuality of suffering, this is the noble actuality of the origin of suffering, this is the noble actuality of the cessation of suffering,

original: ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccan”ti sotāvadhānaṁ, taṁpajānanā
analyzed: ariya saccaḥ idam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā
translated: this is the noble actuality of the way leading to the cessation of suffering”: giving ear thus is understanding consisting in what is heard.🔽Understanding consisting in cogitation is what is meant.

analyzed: paññā sutamaye ñāṇa
translated: How is it understanding consisting in what is heard?

analyzed: tattha katamam dukkham ariya sat ca
translated: Herein, what is the noble actuality of suffering?

original: Jātipi dukkhā, jarāpi dukkhā, maraṇampi dukkhaṁ, sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsāpi🔽dukkhā, appiyehi sampayogo dukkho, piyehi vippayogo dukkho, yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ;
analyzed: jāti pi dukkhā jarā api dukkhā maraṇam pi dukkha soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsā api  dukkhāḥ appiyehi sampayogaḥ dukkhaḥ piyehi vippayogaḥ dukkhaḥ yam piccham na labhati tam pi dukkha
translated: Birth is suffering, ageing is suffering, death is suffering, sorrow and lamentation, pain, grief and despair are suffering,

analyzed: saṅkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā
translated: association with the unloved is suffering, separation from the loved is suffering, not to get what one wants is suffering, in short the five categories of 1 clinging are suffering.

analyzed: tattha katamā jāti
translated: Herein, what is birth?

original: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānaṁ pātubhāvo āyatanānaṁ paṭilābho—
analyzed: yā tesam tesam sattānam tamhi tamhi satta nikāye jāti sañjāti okkanti abhinibbatti khandhānam pātubhāvaḥ āyatanānam paṭilābhaḥ
translated: Whatever birth there is of the various beings in the various orders of beings, their being born, descent , reproduction, manifestation of the aggregates, acquisition of the sense spheres,

analyzed: ayam vuccati jāti
translated: this is called birth.🔽Herein, what is ageing?

original: Tattha katamā jarā yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhi tamhi sattanikāye jarā jīraṇatā khaṇḍiccaṁ pāliccaṁ valittacatā āyuno saṁhāni indriyānaṁ paripāko—
analyzed: tattha katamā jarā yā tesam tesam sattānam tamhi tamhi satta nikāye jarā jīraṇa tā khaṇḍiccam pāliccam valittaca tā āyuno sahāni indriyānam paripākaḥ
translated: Whatever ageing, old age, brokenness of teeth, greyness of hair, wrinkling of skin, decline of life, weakening of faculties of the various beings in the various orders of beings,

analyzed: ayam vuccati jarā
translated: this is called ageing.

analyzed: tattha katamam
translated: Herein, what is death?

original: Yā tesaṁ tesaṁ sattānaṁ tamhā tamhā sattanikāyā cuti cavanatā bhedo antaradhānaṁ maccu maraṇaṁ kālakiriyā khandhānaṁ bhedo kaḷevarassa nikkhepo jīvitindriyassupacchedo—
analyzed: yā tesam tesam sattānam tamhā tamhā satta nikāyā cuti cavana tā bhedaḥ antaradhānam maccu maraṇam kālakiriyā khandhānam bhedaḥ kaḷevarassa nikkhepaḥ jīvitindriyassa upacchedo
translated: Whatever passing away, perishing, dissolution, dying, deceasing, breaking up, death, completion of time, dissolution of the aggregates, throwing off of the coil, separation of the aggregates in the various beings in the various orders of beings,

analyzed: idam vuccati maraṇa
translated: this is called death.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ soko
translated: Herein, what is sorrow?

original: Ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa,
analyzed: ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa
translated: In one who has met with misfortune regarding relatives or with misfortune regarding wealth or with misfortune regarding disease,

original: sīlabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, diṭṭhibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, aññataraññatarena byasanena
analyzed: sīla byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa diṭṭhi byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa aññatara aññatarena byasanena
translated: when touched by loss of virtue, or touched by loss of view, or touched by some misfortune,

original: samannāgatassa, aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa soko socanā socitattaṁ
analyzed: samannāgatassa aññatara aññatarena dukkha dhammena phuṭṭhassa
translated: or touched by some painful feeling, sorrow, grieving, sorrowfulness,

original: antosoko antoparisoko cetaso parijjhāyanā domanassaṁ sokasallaṁ—
analyzed: cetaso parijjhāyanā domanassam soka salla
translated: sorrow within, great sorrow within, mental disturbance, mental disquiet, the dart of sorrow,

analyzed: ayam vuccati sokaḥ
translated: this is called sorrow.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ paridevaḥ
translated: Herein, what is lamentation?

original: Ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa,
analyzed: ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa
translated: when touched by loss of relatives, or touched by loss of wealth, or touched by loss of health,

original: sīlabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, diṭṭhibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, aññataraññatarena byasanena
analyzed: sīla byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa diṭṭhi byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa aññatara aññatarena byasanena
translated: or touched by loss of virtue, or touched by loss of view, or touched by some misfortune,

original: samannāgatassa, aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevo paridevo ādevanā,
analyzed: samannāgatassa aññatara aññatarena dukkha dhammena phuṭṭhassa ādevaḥ paridevaḥ ādevanā
translated: or touched by some painful feeling, lamenting, great lamenting, lamenting in various ways,

original: paridevanā ādevitattaṁ paridevitattaṁ vācā palāpo vippalāpo lālappo lālappanā lālappitattaṁ—
analyzed: paridevanā ādevitattam paridevitattam vācā palāpaḥ vippalāpaḥ lālappaḥ lālappanā lālappitattam
translated: wailing, great wailing, wailing in various ways, lamenting in various ways with a voice that is broken and tearful,

analyzed: ayam vuccati paridevaḥ
translated: this is called lamentation.

analyzed: tattha katamaṃ
translated: Herein, what is pain?

original: Yaṁ kāyikaṁ asātaṁ kāyikaṁ dukkhaṁ kāyasamphassajaṁ asātaṁ dukkhaṁ vedayitaṁ, kāyasamphassajā asātā dukkhā vedanā—
analyzed: yam kāyikam asātam kāyikam dukkham kāya samphassa jam asātam dukkham vedayita kāya samphassa jā asātā dukkhā vedanā
translated: Whatever bodily pain, bodily discomfort, that is sensed as painful, sensed as discomforting born of body-contact, painful feeling born of body-contact—

analyzed: idam vuccati dukkha
translated: this is called pain.

analyzed: tattha katamam domanassa
translated: Herein, what is grief?

original: Yaṁ cetasikaṁ asātaṁ cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ, cetosamphassajaṁ asātaṁ dukkhaṁ vedayitaṁ, cetosamphassajā asātā dukkhā vedanā—
analyzed: yam cetasikam asātam cetasikam dukkha cetas samphassa jam asātam dukkham vedayita cetaḥ samphassa jā asātā dukkhā vedanā
translated: Whatever mental pain, mental discomfort, that is sensed as painful, sensed as discomforting born of mind-contact, painful feeling born of mind-contact—

analyzed: idam vuccati domanassa
translated: this is called grief.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ upāyāso
translated: Herein, what is despair?

original: Ñātibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, bhogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, rogabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa,
analyzed: ñāti byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa bhoga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa roga byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa
translated: When one affected by loss of relatives or loss of wealth or loss of health🔽or loss of virtue or loss of view,

original: sīlabyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, diṭṭhibyasanena vā phuṭṭhassa, aññataraññatarena byasanena🔽samannāgatassa, aññataraññatarena dukkhadhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāso upāyāso āyāsanā
analyzed: sīla byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa diṭṭhi byasanena vā phuṭṭhassa aññatara aññatarena byasanena  samannāgatassa aññatara aññatarena dukkha dhammena phuṭṭhassa āyāsaḥ upāyāsaḥ āyāsanā
translated: or affected by some misfortune or other,

analyzed: upāyāsanāḥ āyāsitattam
translated: or affected by some painful feeling or other, is distressed, despairing, distressed in mind, despairing in mind,

analyzed: ayam vuccati upāyāso
translated: this is called despair.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ appiyehi sampayogaḥ dukkho
translated: Herein, what is association with the unloved as suffering?

original: Idha yassa te honti aniṭṭhā akantā amanāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā, ye
analyzed: idha yassa te honti aniṭṭhāḥ akantāḥ amanāpāḥ rūpā saddāḥ gandhāḥ rasā phoṭṭhabbāḥ ye
translated: Here, whatever is unwanted, disagreeable, displeasing, and ill-favored forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangibles,

original: vā panassa te honti anatthakāmā ahitakāmā aphāsukāmā ayogakkhemakāmā, yā tehi saddhiṁ
analyzed: vā panassa te honti anattha kāmāḥ ahita kāmāḥ a phāsu kāmāḥ a yogakkhema kāmāḥ yā tehi saddhi
translated: or whatever wishes for harm, wishes for misfortune, wishes for affliction, and wishes for non-prosperity,

analyzed: saṅgati samāgamaḥ samodhānam missībhāvaḥ
translated: the coming together, meeting, and occurrence of those things, the fact of being mixed up with them,

analyzed: ayam vuccati appiyehi sampayogaḥ dukkho
translated: this is called association with what is not dear as suffering.

original: Tattha katamo piyehi vippayogo dukkho?🔽Idha yassa te honti iṭṭhā kantā manāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā, ye vā panassa
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ piyehi vippayogaḥ dukkho  idha yassa te honti iṭṭhā kantā manāpā rūpā saddā gandhā rasā phoṭṭhabbā ye vā panassa
translated: Herein, what is separation from what is dear as suffering?

original: te honti atthakāmā hitakāmā phāsukāmā yogakkhemakāmā mātā vā pitā vā bhātā vā bhaginī
analyzed: te honti attha kāmāḥ hita kāmā phāsu kāmāḥ yogakkhema kāmāḥ mātā vā pitā vā bhātā vā bhaginī
translated: Here, whatever is wanted, agreeable, pleasing, and attractive forms, sounds, smells, tastes, and tangibles, or whatever wishes for welfare, wishes for happiness, wishes for prosperity, and wishes for security, such as mother, father, brother, sister,

original: vā mittā vā amaccā vā ñātī vā sālohitā vā, yā tehi saddhiṁ asaṅgati asamāgamo asamodhānaṁ amissībhāvo—
analyzed: vā mittāḥ vā amaccāḥ vā ñātī vā sālohitāḥ vā yā tehi saddhim a saṅgati a samāgamaḥ a samodhānam a missībhāvaḥ
translated: friends, companions, and relatives, the non-coming together, non-meeting, and non-occurrence of those things, the fact of being unmixed with them,

analyzed: ayam vuccati piyehi vippayogaḥ dukkho
translated: this is called separation from what is dear as suffering.

original: Tattha katamaṁ yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ?
analyzed: tattha katamam yam piccham na labhati tam pi dukkha
translated: Herein, what is not getting what one wants as suffering?

analyzed: jāti dhammānam sattānam evam icchā uppajjati
translated: For beings subject to birth, the wish arises:

original: “aho vata mayaṁ na jātidhammā assāma, na ca vata no jāti āgaccheyyā”ti.🔽Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ—
analyzed: aho vata mayam na jāti dhammāḥ assāma na ca vata naḥ jāti āgaccheyya ati  na kho pana itam icchāya pattabba
translated: ‘Oh, if only we weren’t subject to birth, and if only birth wouldn’t come to us.’🔽But you can’t achieve this by wishing.

original: idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.🔽Jarādhammānaṁ sattānaṁ …pe…🔽byādhidhammānaṁ sattānaṁ …
analyzed: idam pi yam piccham na labhati tam pi  jarā dhammānam sattānam pe  byādhi dhammānam sattānam
translated: Not getting what you wish for is suffering.🔽For beings subject to old age …🔽For beings subject to sickness …

analyzed: maraṇa dhammānam sattānam
translated: For beings subject to death …

analyzed: soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsa dhammānam sattānam evam icchā uppajjati
translated: For beings subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, this wish arises:

original: “aho vata mayaṁ na sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsadhammā assāma, na ca vata no sokaparidevadukkhadomanassupāyāsā āgaccheyyun”ti.🔽Na kho panetaṁ icchāya pattabbaṁ—
analyzed: aho vata mayam na soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsa dhammāḥ assāma na ca vata no soka parideva dukkha domanassa upāyāsāḥ āgaccheyyunti  na kho pana itam icchāya pattabba
translated: ‘Oh, if only we weren’t subject to sorrow, lamentation, pain, sadness, and distress, and if only these wouldn’t come to us.’

original: idampi yampicchaṁ na labhati tampi dukkhaṁ.
analyzed: idam pi yam piccham na labhati tam pi
translated: But you can’t achieve this by wishing.🔽Not getting what you wish for is suffering.

analyzed: tattha katame saṅkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhā
translated: What, in brief, are the five grasping aggregates that are suffering?

analyzed: seyyathida
translated: They are:

analyzed: rūpa upādāna khandhaḥ vedanā upādāna khandhaḥ saññu pādāna khandhaḥ saṅkhāru pādāna khandhaḥ viññāṇu pādāna khandhaḥ
translated: the grasping aggregates of form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.

analyzed: ime vuccanti saṅkhittena pañca upādānakkhandhāḥ dukkhāḥ
translated: These, in short, are the five aggregates as objects of clinging that are suffering.

analyzed: idam vuccati dukkham ariya sat ca
translated: This is called the noble truth of suffering.

original: Tattha katamaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ?🔽Yāyaṁ taṇhā ponobhavikā nandirāgasahagatā tatratatrābhinandinī, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: tattha katamam dukkha samudayam ariya sat ca  yā ayam taṇhā ponobhavikā nandi rāga sahagatā tatra tatra abhinandinī
translated: Herein, what is the noble truth of the origin of suffering?🔽It is craving, which brings renewal of being, is accompanied by delight and lust, and delights in this and that; that is, craving for sensual pleasures, craving for being, and craving for non-being.

original: kāmataṇhā bhavataṇhā vibhavataṇhā, sā kho panesā taṇhā kattha uppajjamānā uppajjati, kattha nivisamānā nivisati?
analyzed: kāma taṇhā bhava taṇhā vibhava taṇhā sā kho pana isā taṇhā kattha uppajjamānā uppajjati kattha nivisamānā nivisati
translated: Now, this craving, when and where does it arise and where does it settle?

original: Yaṁ loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
analyzed: yam loke piya rūpam sāta rūpe etthā isā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati etthā nivisamānā nivisati
translated: Whatever in the world is pleasing and desirable, there this craving arises and there it settles.

analyzed: kiñca loke piya rūpam sāta rūpa
translated: And what in the world is pleasing and desirable?

original: Cakkhu loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
analyzed: cakkhu loke piya rūpam sāta rūpe ettha īsā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati
translated: The eye in the world is pleasing and desirable; there this craving arises and there it settles.

analyzed: sotam loke pe  ghānam loke
translated: The ear in the world …🔽The nose in the world …

analyzed: jivhā loke
translated: The tongue in the world …

analyzed: kāyaḥ loke
translated: The body in the world …

original: mano loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
analyzed: manaḥ loke piya rūpam sāta rūpaḥ etthā isā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati
translated: The mind in the world is pleasing and desirable; there this craving arises and there it settles.

original: Rūpā loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
analyzed: rūpāḥ loke piya rūpam sāta rūpe ettha īsā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati
translated: Forms in the world are likable and pleasing, and it’s here that craving arises and settles.

analyzed: saddā loke piya rūpam sāta rūpam
translated: Sounds in the world …

analyzed: dhammāḥ loke  cakkhu viññāṇam loke pe  manaḥ viññāṇam loke
translated: Ideas in the world …🔽Eye consciousness in the world …🔽Mind consciousness in the world …

analyzed: cakkhu samphassaḥ loke pe
translated: Eye contact in the world …

analyzed: manaḥ samphassaḥ loke
translated: Mind contact in the world …

analyzed: cakkhu samphassa jā vedanā loke pe
translated: Eye-contact-born feeling in the world …

analyzed: manaḥ samphassa jā vedanā loke
translated: Mind-contact-born feeling in the world …

analyzed: rūpa saññā loke pe
translated: Perception of forms in the world …

analyzed: dhamma saññā loke
translated: Perception of ideas in the world …

analyzed: rūpa sañcetanā loke
translated: Choice of forms in the world …

analyzed: dhamma sañcetanā loke
translated: Choice of ideas in the world …

analyzed: rūpa taṇhāḥ loke pe
translated: Craving for forms in the world …

analyzed: dhamma taṇhā loke
translated: Craving for ideas in the world …

analyzed: rūpa vitakkaḥ loke pe
translated: Thinking of forms in the world …

analyzed: dhamma vitakkaḥ loke
translated: Thinking of ideas in the world …

analyzed: rūpa vicāraḥ loke pe
translated: Thinking about forms in the world …

original: dhammavicāro loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati, ettha nivisamānā nivisati.
analyzed: dhamma vicāraḥ loke piya rūpam sāta rūpaḥ ettha īsā taṇhā uppajjamānā uppajjati ettha nivisamānā nivisati
translated: Thinking about ideas in the world are likable and pleasing, and it’s here that craving arises and settles.

analyzed: idam vuccati dukkha samudayam ariya sat ca
translated: This is called the noble truth of the origination of stress.

analyzed: tattha katamam dukkha nirodham ariya sat ca
translated: “And what is the noble truth of the cessation of stress?

original: Yo tassāyeva taṇhāya asesavirāganirodho cāgo paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo, sā kho panesā taṇhā kattha pahīyamānā pahīyati, kattha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati?
analyzed: yaḥ tassāya eva taṇhāya asesa virāga nirodho cāgaḥ paṭinissaggo mutti anālayo sā kho pana isā taṇhā kattha pahīyamānā pahīyati kattha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati
translated: And where does this craving cease without remainder?

original: Yaṁ loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
analyzed: yam loke piya rūpam sāta rūpe etthā isā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati etthā nirujjhamānā nirujjhati
translated: Wherever there is an agreeable and pleasurable thing in the world, it is here that craving ceases without remainder.

original: Kiñca loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ?🔽Cakkhuloke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati …pe…
analyzed: kiñca loke piya rūpam sāta rūpa  cakkhu loke piya rūpam sāta rūpe ettha isā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati pe
translated: And what is the agreeable and pleasurable thing in the world?🔽The eye is an agreeable and pleasurable thing in the world. It is here that craving ceases without remainder.

original: dhammavicāro loke piyarūpaṁ sātarūpaṁ, etthesā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati, ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati.
analyzed: dhamma vicāraḥ loke piya rūpam sāta rūpaḥ ettha isā taṇhā pahīyamānā pahīyati ettha nirujjhamānā nirujjhati
translated: The ear … the nose … the tongue … the body … the mind is an agreeable and pleasurable thing in the world. It is here that craving ceases without remainder.

analyzed: idam vuccati dukkha nirodham ariya sat ca
translated: This is called the noble truth of the cessation of suffering.

analyzed: tattha katamam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya sat ca
translated: “And what is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering?

analyzed: ayam eva ariyaḥ aṭṭhaṅgikaḥ maggo
translated: It is this noble eightfold path, namely, right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

original: sammādiṭṭhi sammāsaṅkappo sammāvācā sammākammanto sammāājīvo sammāvāyāmo sammāsati sammāsamādhi.
analyzed: sammā diṭṭhi sammā saṅkappo sammā vācā sammā kammanto sammā ājīvaḥ sammā vāyāmaḥ sammā sati sammā samādhi
translated: Right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration.

analyzed: tattha katamā sammādiṭṭhi
translated: Herein, what is right view?

original: Dukkhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhasamudaye ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhe ñāṇaṁ, dukkhanirodhagāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇaṁ—
analyzed: dukkhe ñāṇa dukkha samudaye ñāṇa dukkha nirodhe ñāṇa dukkha nirodha gāminiyā paṭipadāya ñāṇa
translated: Knowledge of suffering, knowledge of the origin of suffering, knowledge of the cessation of suffering, knowledge of the way leading to the cessation of suffering—

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammādiṭṭhi
translated: this is called right view.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ sammāsaṅkappo
translated: Herein, what is right thought?

analyzed: nekkhamma saṅkappo a byāpāda saṅkappo a vihisā saṅkappo
translated: Renunciation, non-ill will, and non-cruelty—

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammāsaṅkappo
translated: this is called right thought.

analyzed: tattha katamā sammāvācā
translated: Herein, what is right speech?

original: Musāvādā veramaṇī, pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī, pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī, samphappalāpā veramaṇī—
analyzed: musāvādā veramaṇī pisuṇāya vācāya veramaṇī pharusāya vācāya veramaṇī samphappalāpā veramaṇī
translated: Abstinence from false speech, abstinence from malicious speech, abstinence from rough speech, abstinence from gossip—

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammā vācā
translated: this is called right speech.

analyzed: tattha katamo sammākammanto
translated: Herein, what is right action?

original: Pāṇātipātā veramaṇī, adinnādānā veramaṇī, kāmesumicchācārā veramaṇī—
analyzed: pāṇa atipātā veramaṇī adinna ādānā veramaṇī kāmesumicchā ācārā veramaṇī
translated: Abstinence from killing living beings, abstinence from taking what is not given, abstinence from misconduct in sensual pleasures—

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammākammanto
translated: this is called right action.

analyzed: tattha katamaḥ sammāājīvo
translated: Herein, what is right livelihood?

original: Idha ariyasāvako micchāājīvaṁ pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikaṁ kappeti—
analyzed: idha ariya sāvakaḥ micchāājīvam pahāya sammāājīvena jīvikam kappeti
translated: There is the case where a disciple of the noble ones, abandoning the pursuit of sensual pleasures, doesn’t pursue them as he did before.

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammāājīvo
translated: This is called right livelihood.

original: Tattha katamo sammāvāyāmo?🔽Idha bhikkhu anuppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ anuppādāya chandaṁ janeti
analyzed: tattha katamaḥ sammāvāyāmo  idha bhikkhu an uppannānam pāpakānam akusalānam dhammānam an uppādāya chandam janeti
translated: “And what is right effort?

original: vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati, uppannānaṁ pāpakānaṁ akusalānaṁ
analyzed: vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati uppannānam pāpakānam akusalāna
translated: There is the case where a monk generates desire, endeavors, arouses persistence, upholds & exerts his intent for the sake of the non-arising of evil, unskillful qualities that have not yet arisen…

analyzed: dhammānam pahānāya pe
translated: for the sake of the abandoning of evil, unskillful qualities that have arisen…

analyzed: anuppannānam kusalānam dhammānaṃ uppādāya pe
translated: for the sake of the arising of skillful qualities that have not yet arisen…

original: uppannānaṁ kusalānaṁ dhammānaṁ ṭhitiyā asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandaṁ janeti vāyamati vīriyaṁ ārabhati cittaṁ paggaṇhāti padahati—
analyzed: uppannānam kusalānam dhammānam ṭhitiyāḥ asammosāya bhiyyobhāvāya vepullāya bhāvanāya pāripūriyā chandam janeti vāyamati vīriyam ārabhati cittam paggaṇhāti padahati
translated: for the maintenance, non-confusion, increase, plenitude, development, & culmination of skillful qualities that have arisen.

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammāvāyāmo
translated: This is called right effort.

analyzed: tattha katamā sammā asati
translated: “And what is right mindfulness?

original: Idha bhikkhu kāye kāyānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ.🔽Vedanāsu …pe…
analyzed: idha bhikkhu kāye kāya anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa  vedanāsu pe
translated: There is the case where a monk remains focused on the body in & of itself—ardent, alert, & mindful—subduing greed & distress with reference to the world.

analyzed: citte pe
translated: He remains focused on feelings in & of themselves…🔽He remains focused on the mind in & of itself…

original: dhammesu dhammānupassī viharati ātāpī sampajāno satimā vineyya loke abhijjhādomanassaṁ—
analyzed: dhammesu dhamma anupassī viharati ātāpī sampajānaḥ satimā vineyya loke abhijjhā domanassa
translated: He dwells contemplating (the nature of) things in (various) things, ardent, clearly knowing, and mindful, after removing avarice and sorrow regarding the world.

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammā sati
translated: This is called right mindfulness.

original: Tattha katamo sammāsamādhi?🔽Idha bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: tattha katamo sammāsamādhi  idha bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: Herein, what is right concentration?🔽Here a monk, quite secluded from sense desires, secluded from unwholesome things, having thinking, reflection, and happiness and bliss born of seclusion, dwells having attained the first absorption.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the stilling of thinking and reflection, with internal clarity and one-pointedness of mind, being without thinking, without reflection, having the happiness and bliss born of concentration, he dwells having attained the second absorption.

original: Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti,
analyzed: pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ ca sampajāno sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti
translated: With the fading away of happiness (he dwells) equanimous, mindful, and clearly knowing, experiencing bliss through his body,

original: yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti—“upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī”ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: he dwells having attained the third absorption, of which the noble ones declare: “He is equanimous, mindful, one who dwells happily.”

original: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: On the dissolution of pleasure and pain… he enters and dwells in the fourth jhāna…

analyzed: ayam vuccati sammāsamādhi
translated: This is called right concentration.

analyzed: idam vuccati dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ariya sat ca
translated: This is called the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering.

original: Taṁ ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṁ, pajānanaṭṭhena paññā.🔽Tena vuccati—🔽“idaṁ dukkhaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhasamudayaṁ ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhanirodhaṁ
analyzed: tam ñāta ṭṭhena pajānana ṭṭhena paññā  tena vuccati  idam dukkham ariya sacca idam dukkha samudayam ariya sacca idam dukkha nirodha
translated: It is knowledge in the sense of knowing, understanding in the sense of discerning.🔽Hence ‘this is the noble truth of suffering’, ‘this is the noble truth of the origin of suffering’, ‘this is the noble truth of the cessation of suffering’,

original: ariyasaccaṁ, idaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā ariyasaccan”ti sotāvadhānaṁ, taṁpajānanā🔽paññā sutamaye ñāṇaṁ.
analyzed: ariya saccaḥ idam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā  paññā sutamaye ñāṇa
translated: ‘this is the noble truth of the way leading to the cessation of suffering’ is hearing; the act of discerning that is understanding.🔽Understanding that is knowledge consisting in what is heard.

analyzed: evam sota avadhāne paññā suta maye
translated: So understanding in hearing is knowledge consisting in what is heard.

analyzed: suta maya ñāṇa niddeso paṭhamo  sīla maya ñāṇa niddesa
translated: The Description of Knowledge Consisting in What is Heard is the first.🔽… The Description of Knowledge Consisting in What is Said

original: Kathaṁ sutvāna saṁvare paññā sīlamaye ñāṇaṁ?
analyzed: katham sutvāna savare paññā sīla maye ñāṇa
translated: How is it that understanding in the act of restraining after hearing is knowledge consisting in what is said?

analyzed: pañca sīlāni
translated: There are five precepts:🔽…

analyzed: pariyanta pārisuddhi sīla apariyanta pārisuddhi sīla paripuṇṇa pārisuddhi sīla aparāmaṭṭha pārisuddhi sīla paṭippassaddhi pārisuddhi sīlanti
translated: virtue that is purified by limitation, virtue that is purified by non-limitation, virtue that is purified by fulfilment, virtue that is purified by non-grasping, virtue that is purified by surmounting.

analyzed: tattha katamam
translated: Herein, what is virtue that is purified by limitation?

analyzed: an upasampannānam
translated: The training precepts of those not fully admitted to the Order:

analyzed: idam
translated: this is virtue that is purified by limitation.

analyzed: katamam
translated: What is virtue that is purified by non-limitation?

analyzed: upasampannānam a pariyanta sikkhāpadānam
translated: The training precepts of those fully admitted to the Order:

analyzed: idam a pariyanta pārisuddhi sīla
translated: this is virtue that is purified by non-limitation.

analyzed: katamam paripuṇṇa pārisuddhi sīla
translated: What is virtue that is purified by fulfilment?

original: Puthujjanakalyāṇakānaṁ kusaladhamme yuttānaṁ sekkhapariyante paripūrakārīnaṁ kāye ca jīvite ca anapekkhānaṁ pariccattajīvitānaṁ—
analyzed: puthujjana kalyāṇakānam kusala dhamme yuttānam sekkha pariyante paripūra kārīnam kāye ca jīvite ca an apekkhānam pariccatta jīvitānam
translated: That of good persons among ordinary men who are occupied with profitable things and who fulfil the limit of what can be achieved by those in training, who are unconcerned with body and life, who have renounced all:

analyzed: idam paripuṇṇa pārisuddhi sīla
translated: this is virtue that is purified by fulfilment.

analyzed: katamam
translated: What is virtue that is purified by non-grasping?

analyzed: sattannam sekkhāna
translated: That of the seven kinds of ordinary disciples:

analyzed: idam
translated: this is virtue that is purified by non-grasping.

analyzed: katamam paṭippassaddhi pārisuddhi sīla
translated: What is virtue that is purified by surmounting?

original: Tathāgatasāvakānaṁ khīṇāsavānaṁ paccekabuddhānaṁ tathāgatānaṁ arahantānaṁ sammāsambuddhānaṁ—
analyzed: tathāgata sāvakānam khīṇāsavānam paccekabuddhānam tathāgatānam arahantānam sammāsambuddhānam
translated: the disciples of the Tathāgata, those who have attained the destruction of the taints, the individual Buddhas, the Worthy Ones, the Perfect Sambuddhas—

analyzed: idam paṭippassaddhi pārisuddhi sīla
translated: this is the virtue of purification by overcoming.

original: Atthi sīlaṁ pariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ apariyantaṁ.
analyzed: atthi sīlam a pariyanta
translated: There is virtue that has a limit, and there is virtue that is unlimited.

analyzed: tattha katamam tam sīlam pariyanta
translated: Herein, what is the virtue that has a limit?

original: Atthi sīlaṁ lābhapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ yasapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ ñātipariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ aṅgapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ jīvitapariyantaṁ.
analyzed: atthi sīlam lābha pariyanta atthi sīlam yasa pariyanta atthi sīlam ñāti pariyanta atthi sīlam aṅga pariyanta atthi sīlam jīvita pariyanta
translated: There is virtue that has gain as its limit, there is virtue that has fame as its limit, there is virtue that has relatives as its limit, there is virtue that has bodily-form as its limit, there is virtue that has life as its limit.

original: Katamaṁ taṁ sīlaṁ lābhapariyantaṁ?🔽Idhekacco lābhahetu lābhapaccayā lābhakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamati—
analyzed: katamam tam sīlam lābha pariyanta  idha ekaccaḥ lābha hetu lābha paccayā lābha kāraṇā yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamati
translated: Herein, what is the virtue that has gain as its limit?

analyzed: idam tam sīlam lābha pariyanta
translated: Here someone, for the sake of gain, because of gain, for the sake of fame, because of fame, for the sake of relatives, because of relatives, for the sake of bodily-form, because of bodily-form, for the sake of life, because of life, transgresses the training rules as they have been laid down—🔽this is the virtue that has gain as its limit.

original: Katamaṁ taṁ sīlaṁ yasapariyantaṁ?🔽Idhekacco yasahetu yasapaccayā yasakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamati—
analyzed: katamam tam sīlam  idha ekaccaḥ yasa hetu yasa paccayā yasa kāraṇā yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamati
translated: Herein, what is the virtue that has fame as its limit?

analyzed: idam tam sīlam
translated: Here someone, for the sake of fame, because of fame, for the sake of gain, because of gain, for the sake of relatives, because of relatives, for the sake of bodily-form, because of bodily-form, for the sake of life, because of life, transgresses the training rules as they have been laid down—🔽this is the virtue that has fame as its limit.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam
translated: Herein, what is the virtue that has relatives as its limit?

original: Idhekacco ñātihetu ñātipaccayā ñātikāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamati—
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ ñāti hetu ñāti paccayā ñāti kāraṇā yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamati
translated: “Here someone transgresses a training rule he has accepted because of relatives, for the sake of relatives, on account of relatives.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam
translated: This is virtue limited by relatives.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam
translated: “What is virtue limited by component?

original: Idhekacco aṅgahetu aṅgapaccayā aṅgakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamati—
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ aṅga hetu aṅga paccayāḥ aṅga kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamati
translated: “Here someone transgresses a training rule he has accepted because of components, for the sake of components, on account of components.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam
translated: This is virtue limited by components.

original: Katamaṁ taṁ sīlaṁ jīvitapariyantaṁ?🔽Idhekacco jīvitahetu jīvitapaccayā jīvitakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamati—
analyzed: katamam tam sīlam jīvita pariyanta  idha ekaccaḥ jīvita hetu jīvita paccayāḥ jīvita kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamati
translated: “What is virtue limited by life?🔽“Here someone transgresses a training rule he has accepted because of life, for the sake of life, on account of life.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam jīvita pariyanta
translated: This is virtue limited by life.

original: Evarūpāni sīlāni khaṇḍāni chiddāni sabalāni kammāsāni na bhujissāni na viññuppasatthāni
analyzed: evarūpāni sīlāni khaṇḍāni chiddāni sabalāni kammāsāni na bhujissāni na viññuppasatthāni
translated: Such virtues are broken, corrupted, blemished, disfigured, tainted, rejected, despised by wise ascetics and brahmins.

original: parāmaṭṭhāni asamādhisaṁvattanikāni na avippaṭisāravatthukāni na pāmojjavatthukāni
analyzed: parāmaṭṭhāni asamādhi savattanikāni na a vippaṭisāra vatthukāni na pāmojja vatthukāni
translated: They are not conducive to freedom from remorse,🔽not conducive to joy,🔽not conducive to rapture,🔽not conducive to tranquility,

original: na pītivatthukāni na passaddhivatthukāni na sukhavatthukāni na samādhivatthukāni
analyzed: na pīti vatthukāni na passaddhi vatthukāni na sukha vatthukāni na samādhi vatthukāni
translated: not conducive to bliss,🔽not conducive to right concentration,

original: na yathābhūtañāṇadassanavatthukāni na ekantanibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na
analyzed: na yathābhūta ñāṇa dassana vatthukāni na ekanta nibbidāya na virāgāya na nirodhāya na
translated: not the basis for knowledge and vision in accordance with reality, not for complete disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbāna.

original: upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya saṁvattanti—
analyzed: upasamāya na abhiññāya na sambodhāya na nibbānāya savattanti
translated: are not the basis for knowledge & vision as it really is, are not conducive to disenchantment, to dispassion, to cessation, to stilling, to direct knowledge, to self-awakening, to unbinding—

analyzed: idam tam sīlam pariyanta
translated: this is the virtue that has a limit.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam apariyanta
translated: “And what is the virtue that has no limit?

original: Atthi sīlaṁ na lābhapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ na yasapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ na ñātipariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ na aṅgapariyantaṁ, atthi sīlaṁ na jīvitapariyantaṁ.
analyzed: atthi sīlam na lābha pariyanta atthi sīlam na yasa pariyanta atthi sīlam na ñāti pariyanta atthi sīlam na aṅga pariyanta atthi sīlam na jīvita pariyanta
translated: There is the case where the virtue is not limited by gain, not limited by reputation, not limited by status, not limited by praise, not limited by pleasure, not limited by possessions, not limited by life.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam na
translated: “And what is the virtue that is not limited by gain?

original: Idhekacco lābhahetu lābhapaccayā lābhakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamāya cittampi na uppādeti, kiṁ so vītikkamissati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ lābha hetu lābha paccayāḥ lābha kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamāya cittam pi na uppādeti kim saḥ vītikkamissati
translated: There is the case where one does not generate even a single thought of sensual desire for the sake of gain, for the sake of reputation, for the sake of status, for the sake of praise, for the sake of pleasure, for the sake of possessions, for the sake of life.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam na
translated: This is the virtue that is not limited by gain.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam na
translated: “And what is the virtue that is not limited by reputation?

original: Idhekacco yasahetu yasapaccayā yasakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamāya cittampi na uppādeti, kiṁ so vītikkamissati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ yasa hetu yasa paccayāḥ yasa kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamāya cittam pi na uppādeti kim saḥ vītikkamissati
translated: Here someone does not arouse even a thought of transgressing a training precept for the sake of fame, for the sake of gain, for the sake of status, for the sake of worldly pleasures, for the sake of a kingdom, for the sake of these worlds.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam na
translated: This is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of fame.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam na
translated: “And what is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of relatives?

original: Idhekacco ñātihetu ñātipaccayā ñātikāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamāya cittampi na uppādeti, kiṁ so vītikkamissati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ ñāti hetu ñāti paccayā ñāti kāraṇā yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamāya cittam pi na uppādeti kim saḥ vītikkamissati
translated: Here someone does not arouse even a thought of transgressing a training precept for the sake of relatives, for the sake of kinsmen, for the sake of friends, for the sake of companions, for the sake of blood-kinsmen, for the sake of guests, for the sake of neighbors, for the sake of relatives by marriage, for the sake of those born in the same place, for the sake of those born in the same village, for the sake of those born in the same country, for the sake of those born in the same town, for the sake of those born in the same street, for the sake of those born in the same neighborhood, for the sake of those born in the same clan, for the sake of those born in the same family, for the sake of those born in the same generation.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam na
translated: This is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of relatives.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam na
translated: “And what is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of limbs?

original: Idhekacco aṅgahetu aṅgapaccayā aṅgakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamāya cittampi na uppādeti, kiṁ so vītikkamissati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ aṅga hetu aṅga paccayāḥ aṅga kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamāya cittam pi na uppādeti kim saḥ vītikkamissati
translated: Here someone does not arouse even a thought of transgressing a training precept for the sake of limbs, for the sake of faculties, for the sake of the body, for the sake of the head, for the sake of the eyes, for the sake of the ears, for the sake of the nose, for the sake of the tongue, for the sake of the body, for the sake of the mind.

analyzed: idam tam sīlam na
translated: This is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of limbs.

analyzed: katamam tam sīlam na
translated: “And what is the virtue that is not limited by a measure of life?

original: Idhekacco jīvitahetu jīvitapaccayā jīvitakāraṇā yathāsamādinnaṁ sikkhāpadaṁ vītikkamāya cittampi na uppādeti, kiṁ so vītikkamissati.
analyzed: idha ekaccaḥ jīvita hetu jīvita paccayāḥ jīvita kāraṇāḥ yathā samādinnam sikkhāpadam vītikkamāya cittam pi na uppādeti kim saḥ vītikkamissati
translated: Here someone does not arouse even a thought of transgression for the sake of life, for the sake of life’s requisites, for the sake of life’s conveniences. How then could he actually commit an offence?

original: Idaṁ taṁ sīlaṁ na jīvitapariyantaṁ.🔽Evarūpāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni
analyzed: idam tam sīlam na  evarūpāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni a sabalāni a kammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni
translated: Here someone does not arouse even a thought of transgressing a training rule for the sake of life, for the sake of life’s requisites, or for the sake of life itself.🔽This is the virtue that is not limited to life.

analyzed: aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhi savattanikāni a vippaṭisāra vatthukāni pāmojja vatthukāni pīti vatthukāni
translated: Such virtue is unbroken, flawless, unblemished, unblotched, liberating, praised by the observant, ungrasped at, and conducive to concentration.

analyzed: passaddhi vatthukāni sukha vatthukāni samādhi vatthukāni yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassana vatthukāni
translated: It is the basis for non-remorse, joy, rapture, tranquility, happiness, concentration, knowledge, and vision of things as they really are.

original: ekantanibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti—
analyzed: ekanta nibbidāya virāgāya nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattanti
translated: It leads to complete disenchantment, dispassion, cessation, peace, direct knowledge, enlightenment, and Nibbana.

original: idaṁ taṁ sīlaṁ apariyantaṁ.🔽Kiṁ sīlaṁ?🔽Kati sīlāni?
analyzed: idam tam sīlam apariyanta  kim sīla  kati sīlāni
translated: This is the virtue that is unlimited.🔽What is virtue?🔽How many kinds of virtue are there?

analyzed: kim samuṭṭhānam sīla
translated: What is the origin of virtue?

analyzed: kati dhamma samodhānam sīla
translated: How many things come together in virtue?

original: Kiṁ sīlanti cetanā sīlaṁ, cetasikaṁ sīlaṁ, saṁvaro sīlaṁ, avītikkamo sīlaṁ.
analyzed: kim sīlanti cetanā sīla cetasikam sīla savaraḥ sīla a vītikkamaḥ sīla
translated: What is virtue? Virtue is volition, virtue is a mental property, virtue is restraint, virtue is non- transgression.

analyzed: kati sīlāni iti tīṇi sīlāni
translated: How many kinds of virtue are there? There are three kinds of virtue:

original: kusalasīlaṁ, akusalasīlaṁ, abyākatasīlaṁ.🔽Kiṁ samuṭṭhānaṁ sīlanti kusalacittasamuṭṭhānaṁ kusalasīlaṁ, akusalacittasamuṭṭhānaṁ akusalasīlaṁ, abyākatacittasamuṭṭhānaṁ abyākatasīlaṁ.
analyzed: kusala sīla akusala sīla abyākata sīla  kim samuṭṭhānam sīlanti kusala citta samuṭṭhānam kusala sīla akusala citta samuṭṭhānam akusala sīla abyākata citta samuṭṭhānam abyākata sīla
translated: virtue that is wholesome, virtue that is unwholesome, virtue that is indeterminate.🔽What is the origin of virtue? Wholesome virtue has wholesome consciousness as its origin; unwholesome virtue has unwholesome consciousness as its origin; indeterminate virtue has indeterminate consciousness as its origin.

original: Kati dhammasamodhānaṁ sīlanti saṁvarasamodhānaṁ sīlaṁ, avītikkamasamodhānaṁ sīlaṁ, tathābhāve jātacetanāsamodhānaṁ sīlaṁ.🔽Pāṇātipātaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: kati dhamma samodhānam sīla nti savara samodhānam sīla avītikkama samodhānam sīla tathā bhāve jāta cetanā samodhānam sīla  pāṇātipātam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: How many things are combined in virtue? Restraint is combined in virtue; non-transgression is combined in virtue; the volition of such a state is combined in virtue.🔽Refraining from killing living beings is virtue in the sense of restraint, virtue in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Adinnādānaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.🔽Kāmesumicchācāraṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.🔽Musāvādaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: adinnādānam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla  kāmesum icchā ācāram savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla  musāvādam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: Refraining from taking what is not given is virtue in the sense of restraint, virtue in the sense of non-transgression.🔽Refraining from sexual misconduct is virtue in the sense of restraint, virtue in the sense of non-transgression.🔽Refraining from false speech is virtue in the sense of restraint, virtue in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Pisuṇaṁ vācaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: pisuṇam vācam savara aṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama aṭṭhena sīla
translated: Refraining from malicious speech is virtue in the sense of restraint, virtue in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Pharusaṁ vācaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.🔽Samphappalāpaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: pharusam vācam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla  samphappalāpam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: Harsh speech is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.🔽Frivolous speech is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Abhijjhaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.🔽Byāpādaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.🔽Micchādiṭṭhiṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: abhijjham savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla  byāpādam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla  micchādiṭṭhim savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: Covetousness is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.🔽Ill will is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.🔽Wrong view is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Nekkhammena kāmacchandaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: nekkhammena kāmacchandam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: Sensual desire is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.

original: Abyāpādena byāpādaṁ saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: a byāpādena byāpādam savara ṭṭhena sīla a vītikkama ṭṭhena sīla
translated: Ill will is virtue in the sense of restraint, in the sense of non-transgression.

analyzed: āloka saññāya thinam iddham
translated: Sloth and torpor by the perception of light …

analyzed: avikkhepa ṭṭhena uddhaccam
translated: Restlessness and remorse by non-distraction …

analyzed: dhamma vavatthānena vicikiccham
translated: Doubt by defining of ideas …

analyzed: ñāṇena avijjam
translated: Ignorance by knowledge …

analyzed: pāmojjena aratim
translated: Aversion by gladness …

analyzed: paṭhamena jhānena nīvaraṇe
translated: The hindrances by the first jhana …

analyzed: dutiyena jhānena vitakka vicāre
translated: Applied and sustained thought by the second jhana …

analyzed: tatiyena jhānena pītim
translated: Happiness by the third jhana …

analyzed: catutthena jhānena sukha dukkham
translated: Pain and pleasure by the fourth jhana …

analyzed: ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpattiyāḥ rūpa saññam paṭigha saññam nānatta saññam
translated: The perception of form, the perception of resistance, the perception of variety, in the attainment of the base of infinite space.

analyzed: viññāṇañcāyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākāsānañcāyatana saññam  ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattiyāḥ viññāṇañcāyatana saññam  nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākiñcañña āyatana sañña
translated: The perception of the base of infinite space, in the attainment of the base of infinite consciousness.🔽The perception of the base of infinite consciousness, in the attainment of the base of nothingness.🔽The perception of the base of nothingness, in the attainment of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

analyzed: anicca anupassanāya nicca saññam
translated: The perception of permanence, in the contemplation of impermanence.

analyzed: dukkha anupassanāya sukha saññam
translated: The perception of pleasure, in the contemplation of pain.

analyzed: anattā anupassanāya atta saññam  nibbida anupassanāya nandim
translated: The perception of self, in the contemplation of not-self.🔽Delight, in the contemplation of disenchantment.

analyzed: virāga anupassanāya rāgam  nirodha anupassanāya samudayam
translated: Passion, in the contemplation of fading away.🔽Arising, in the contemplation of cessation.

analyzed: paṭinissagga anupassanāya ādānam  khaya anupassanāya ghana saññam  vayā anupassanāya āyūhanam
translated: Grasping, in the contemplation of relinquishment.🔽The perception of compactness, in the contemplation of destruction.🔽Accumulation, in the contemplation of fall.

analyzed: vipariṇāma anupassanāya dhuva saññam  a nimitta anupassanāya nimittam
translated: The perception of lastingness, in the contemplation of change.🔽The sign, in the contemplation of the signless.

analyzed: appaṇihita anupassanāya paṇidhim  suññatā anupassanāya abhinivesam
translated: Wish, in the contemplation of the desireless.🔽Clinging, in the contemplation of emptiness.

analyzed: adhi paññā dhamma vipassanāya sāra ādāna abhinivesam
translated: Clinging to rules and observances, and the conceit “I am,” in the higher wisdom of insight into states.

analyzed: yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanena sammoha abhinivesam
translated: “The obsession with delusion …

analyzed: ādīnava anupassanāya ālaya abhinivesam  paṭisaṅkhā anupassanāya appaṭisaṅkham
translated: … with the knowledge and vision of things as they really are, to the misapprehension of confusion …🔽… with the contemplation of drawbacks, to the misapprehension of clinging …🔽… with the contemplation of abandoning, to the non-abandoning …

analyzed: vivaṭṭana anupassanāya saññoga abhinivesam  sotāpatti maggena diṭṭhekaṭṭhe kilese
translated: … with the contemplation of giving up, to the misapprehension of bondage.🔽… with the path of stream-entry, to the defilements that are to be abandoned by seeing …

analyzed: sakadāgāmi maggena oḷārike kilese  anāgāmi maggena aṇu sahagate kilese
translated: … with the path of once-returning, to the gross defilements …🔽… with the path of non-returning, to the subtle defilements …

original: arahattamaggena sabbakilese saṁvaraṭṭhena sīlaṁ, avītikkamaṭṭhena sīlaṁ.
analyzed: arahatta maggena sabba kilese savara aṭṭhena sīla avītikkamaṭṭhena sīla
translated: … with the path of perfection, to all defilements. Restraint is virtue. Non-transgression is virtue.

analyzed: pañca sīlāni
translated: There are five kinds of virtue:

original: pāṇātipātassa pahānaṁ sīlaṁ, veramaṇī sīlaṁ, cetanā sīlaṁ, saṁvaro sīlaṁ, avītikkamo sīlaṁ.
analyzed: pāṇātipātassa pahānam sīla veramaṇī sīla cetanā sīla savaraḥ sīla a vītikkamaḥ sīla
translated: Abandoning killing living beings is virtue. Abstaining from killing living beings is virtue. Intention is virtue. Restraint is virtue. Non-transgression is virtue.

original: Evarūpāni sīlāni cittassa avippaṭisārāya saṁvattanti, pāmojjāya saṁvattanti, pītiyā
analyzed: evarūpāni sīlāni cittassa a vippaṭisārāya savattanti pāmojjāya savattanti pītiyā
translated: Such virtues lead to non-remorse in the mind, to gladdening, to happiness,

original: saṁvattanti, passaddhiyā saṁvattanti, somanassāya saṁvattanti, āsevanāya saṁvattanti,
analyzed: savattanti passaddhiyā savattanti somanassāya savattanti āsevanāya savattanti
translated: to tranquillity, to joy, to repetition,

original: bhāvanāya saṁvattanti, bahulīkammāya saṁvattanti, alaṅkārāya saṁvattanti, parikkhārāya🔽saṁvattanti, parivārāya saṁvattanti, pāripūriyā saṁvattanti, ekantanibbidāya virāgāya🔽nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
analyzed: bhāvanāya savattanti bahulīkammāya savattanti alaṅkārāya savattanti parikkhārāya  savattanti parivārāya savattanti pāripūriyai savattanti ekanta nibbidāya virāgāya  nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattanti
translated: they lead to development, to increase, to cultivation, to fulfilment;🔽they lead to the attainment of the fruit of true knowledge and deliverance; they lead to a pleasant dwelling in this very life; they lead to mindfulness and awareness;

original: Evarūpānaṁ sīlānaṁ saṁvarapārisuddhi adhisīlaṁ, saṁvarapārisuddhiyā ṭhitaṁ cittaṁ
analyzed: evarūpānam sīlānam savara pārisuddhi adhi sīla savara pārisuddhiyā ṭhitam
translated: they lead to the attainment of Nibbana.🔽The purification of virtue is the higher virtue. The mind of one purified in virtue

original: na vikkhepaṁ gacchati, avikkhepapārisuddhi adhicittaṁ saṁvarapārisuddhiṁ sammā passati,🔽avikkhepapārisuddhiṁ sammā passati.
analyzed: na vikkhepam gacchati a vikkhepa pārisuddhi adhicittam savara pārisuddhim sammā passati  avikkhepa pārisuddhim sammā passati
translated: does not incline to restlessness. The purification of the mind is the higher mind. One purified in mind sees things as they really are.

original: Dassanapārisuddhi adhipaññā.🔽Yo tattha saṁvaraṭṭho, ayaṁ adhisīlasikkhā.
analyzed: dassana pārisuddhi adhipaññā  yaḥ tattha savaraṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi sīla sikkhā
translated: The purification by knowledge and vision is the higher wisdom.🔽The restraint therein is the training in the higher virtue.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha a vikkhepa aṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi citta sikkhā
translated: The non-distraction therein is the training in the higher mind.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha dassana ṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi paññā sikkhā
translated: The seeing therein is the training in the higher wisdom.

original: Imā tisso sikkhāyo āvajjanto sikkhati, jānanto sikkhati, passanto sikkhati, paccavekkhanto
analyzed: imā tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ āvajjantaḥ sikkhati jānantaḥ sikkhati passantaḥ sikkhati paccavekkhantaḥ
translated: One who is training thus is mindful; he trains in being mindful. He is aware; he trains in being aware. He is fully aware; he trains in being fully aware.

original: sikkhati, cittaṁ adhiṭṭhahanto sikkhati, saddhāya adhimuccanto sikkhati, vīriyaṁ🔽paggaṇhanto sikkhati, satiṁ upaṭṭhapento sikkhati, cittaṁ samādahanto sikkhati, paññāya🔽pajānanto sikkhati, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto sikkhati, pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto sikkhati,
analyzed: sikkhati cittam adhiṭṭhahantaḥ sikkhati saddhāya adhimuccantaḥ sikkhati vīriya  paggaṇhantaḥ sikkhati satim upaṭṭhapentaḥ sikkhati cittam samādahantaḥ sikkhati paññāya  pajānantaḥ sikkhati abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ sikkhati pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ sikkhati
translated: he trains to attain the mind’s unification; he trains to attain confidence; he trains to attain stillness; he trains to attain happiness; he trains to attain bliss; he trains to attain the mind’s freedom; he trains to attain discernment’s freedom; he trains to attain the knowledge and vision of freedom; he trains to attain the ending of the effluents.

original: pahātabbaṁ pajahanto sikkhati, sacchikātabbaṁ sacchikaronto sikkhati, bhāvetabbaṁ bhāvento sikkhati.
analyzed: pahātabbam pajahantaḥ sikkhati sacchikātabbam sacchikarontaḥ sikkhati bhāvetabbam bhāventaḥ sikkhati
translated: He trains himself to focus on letting go. He trains himself to focus on the mind. He trains himself to focus on confidence. He trains himself to focus on persistence. He trains himself to focus on mindfulness. He trains himself to focus on concentration. He trains himself to focus on wisdom. He trains himself to focus on what should be known. He trains himself to focus on what should be fully known. He trains himself to focus on what should be given up. He trains himself to focus on what should be realized. He trains himself to focus on what should be developed.

analyzed: pañca sīlāni
translated: There are five precepts:🔽against taking life,

analyzed: a dinna ādānassa
translated: against taking what is not given,

analyzed: kāmesumicchācārassa
translated: against sexual misconduct,

analyzed: musāvādassa  pisuṇāya vācāya
translated: against lying,🔽against divisive speech,🔽against harsh speech,

analyzed: pharusāya vācāya  samphappalāpassa  abhijjhāya  byāpādassa
translated: against idle chatter,🔽against covetousness,🔽against ill will,

analyzed: micchādiṭṭhiyā
translated: and against wrong view.

analyzed: nekkhammena kāmacchandassa
translated: Through renunciation, he abandons sensual desire.

analyzed: a byāpādena byāpādassa
translated: Through good will, he abandons ill will.

analyzed: āloka saññāya thinamiddhassa
translated: Through mindfulness of light, he abandons confusion.

analyzed: avikkhepena uddhaccassa
translated: Through non-distraction, he abandons restlessness.

analyzed: dhamma vavatthānena vicikicchāya
translated: Through defining the Dhamma, he abandons doubt.

analyzed: ñāṇena avijjāya
translated: Through knowledge, he abandons ignorance.

analyzed: pāmojjena aratiyā
translated: with joy for disliking …

analyzed: paṭhamena jhānena
translated: with the first absorption for the hindrances …

analyzed: dutiyena jhānena
translated: with the second absorption for thinking and exploring …

analyzed: tatiyena jhānena pītiyā
translated: with the third absorption for rapture …

original: catutthena jhānena sukhadukkhānaṁ …🔽ākāsānañcāyatanasamāpattiyā rūpasaññāya paṭighasaññāya nānattasaññāya …🔽viññāṇañcāyatanasamāpattiyā ākāsānañcāyatanasaññāya …
analyzed: catutthena jhānena sukha dukkhānaṃ  ākāsa anañcāyatana samāpattiyāḥ rūpa saññāya paṭigha saññāya nānatta saññāya  viññāṇañcāyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākāsānañcāyatana saññāya
translated: with the fourth absorption for pleasure and pain …🔽with the dimension of the infinitude of space for the perception of form, the perception of resistance, and the perception of variety …🔽with the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness for the perception of the dimension of the infinitude of space …

analyzed: ākiñcaññāyatana samāpattiyāḥ viññāṇañcāyatana saññāya  nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana samāpattiyāḥ ākiñcañña āyatana saññāya
translated: with the dimension of nothingness for the perception of the dimension of the infinitude of consciousness …🔽with the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception for the perception of the dimension of nothingness …

analyzed: anicca anupassanāya nicca saññāya
translated: with the contemplation of impermanence for the perception of permanence …

analyzed: dukkha anupassanāya sukha saññāya
translated: with the contemplation of suffering for the perception of pleasure …

analyzed: anatta anupassanāya atta saññāya  nibbida anupassanāya nandiyā
translated: with the contemplation of not-self for the perception of self …🔽with the contemplation of dispassion for delight …

analyzed: virāga anupassanāya rāgassa
translated: with the contemplation of fading away for passion …

analyzed: nirodha anupassanāya samudayassa  paṭinissagga anupassanāya ādānassa  khaya anupassanāya ghana saññāya
translated: with the contemplation of cessation for origination …🔽with the contemplation of relinquishment for grasping …

analyzed: vayā anupassanāya āyūhanassa
translated: with the contemplation of destruction for the perception of compactness …🔽with the contemplation of change for the perception of lastingness …

analyzed: vipariṇāma anupassanāya dhuva saññāya  a nimitta anupassanāya nimittassa
translated: “The contemplation of change in the impermanent for the perception of permanence…🔽“The contemplation of the signless in the sign…

analyzed: appaṇihita anupassanāya paṇidhiyā
translated: “The contemplation of the desireless in the desire…

analyzed: suññatā anupassanāya abhinivesassa  adhi paññā dhamma vipassanāya sā rāga abhinivesassa  yathā bhūta ñāṇa dassanena sammoha abhinivesassa
translated: “The contemplation of emptiness in insistence…🔽“The contemplation of reflection on the nature of things in greed…🔽“The knowledge and vision of things as they really are in insistence on delusion…

analyzed: ādīnava anupassanāya ālaya abhinivesassa
translated: “The contemplation of danger in attachment…

analyzed: paṭisaṅkhā anupassanāya appaṭisaṅkhāya
translated: “The contemplation of reflection in non-reflection…

original: vivaṭṭanānupassanāya saññogābhinivesassa.🔽Sotāpattimaggena diṭṭhekaṭṭhānaṁ kilesānaṁ …🔽sakadāgāmimaggena oḷārikānaṁ kilesānaṁ …
analyzed: vivaṭṭana anupassanāya saññoga abhinivesassa  sotāpatti maggena diṭṭha ekaṭṭhānam kilesānam  sakadāgāmi maggena oḷārikānam kilesānam
translated: “The contemplation of turning away in insistence on bondage.

original: anāgāmimaggena anusahagatānaṁ kilesānaṁ …🔽arahattamaggena sabbakilesānaṁ pahānaṁ sīlaṁ, veramaṇī sīlaṁ, cetanā sīlaṁ, saṁvaro sīlaṁ, avītikkamo sīlaṁ.
analyzed: anāgāmi maggena anu sahagatānam kilesānam  arahatta maggena sabba kilesānam pahānam sīla veramaṇī sīla cetanā sīla savaro sīla a vītikkamo sīla
translated: “The abandoning of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of stream-entry is virtue; the abandoning of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of once-return is virtue; the abandoning of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of non-return is virtue; the abandoning of the defilements to be abandoned by the path of arahantship is virtue.

original: Evarūpāni sīlāni cittassa avippaṭisārāya saṁvattanti, pāmojjāya saṁvattanti, pītiyā
analyzed: evarūpāni sīlāni cittassa a vippaṭisārāya savattanti pāmojjāya savattanti pītiyā
translated: “Such virtue as this conduces to non-remorse in the mind, to gladdening, to happiness,

original: saṁvattanti, passaddhiyā saṁvattanti, somanassāya saṁvattanti, āsevanāya saṁvattanti,
analyzed: savattanti passaddhiyā savattanti somanassāya savattanti āsevanāya savattanti
translated: They lead to serenity, to happiness, to concentration, to mindfulness, to equanimity.

original: bhāvanāya saṁvattanti, bahulīkammāya saṁvattanti, alaṅkārāya saṁvattanti, parikkhārāya🔽saṁvattanti, parivārāya saṁvattanti, pāripūriyā saṁvattanti, ekantanibbidāya virāgāya🔽nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya saṁvattanti.
analyzed: bhāvanāya savattanti bahulīkammāya savattanti alaṅkārāya savattanti parikkhārāya  savattanti parivārāya savattanti pāripūriyai savattanti ekanta nibbidāya virāgāya  nirodhāya upasamāya abhiññāya sambodhāya nibbānāya savattanti
translated: They lead to development, to cultivation, to much practice, to adornment, to fulfilment, to a companion, to abundance, to fulfilment.

original: Evarūpānaṁ sīlānaṁ saṁvarapārisuddhi adhisīlaṁ.🔽Saṁvarapārisuddhiyā ṭhitaṁ cittaṁ avikkhepaṁ gacchati, avikkhepapārisuddhi adhicittaṁ.
analyzed: evarūpānam sīlānam adhi sīla  savara pārisuddhiyā ṭhitam cittam avikkhepam gacchati avikkhepa pārisuddhi adhi citta
translated: They lead to complete disenchantment, to dispassion, to cessation, to peace, to direct knowledge, to enlightenment, to Nibbāna.🔽Such virtue as this is purification of virtue by restraint.🔽When the mind is steadied by purification of virtue, it becomes concentrated and single, and enters upon the way to unification. This is purification of mind by concentration.

original: Saṁvarapārisuddhiṁ sammā passati, avikkhepapārisuddhiṁ sammā passati.
analyzed: savara pārisuddhim sammā passati avikkhepa pārisuddhim sammā passati
translated: He sees the purification of virtue and the purification of mind as they really are.

original: Dassanapārisuddhi adhipaññā.🔽Yo tattha saṁvaraṭṭho, ayaṁ adhisīlasikkhā.
analyzed: dassana pārisuddhi adhipaññā  yaḥ tattha savaraṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi sīla sikkhā
translated: This is purification of view by knowledge.🔽The state of restraint in this context is training in the higher virtue.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha a vikkhepa aṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi citta sikkhā
translated: The state of non-distraction in this context is training in the higher consciousness.

analyzed: yaḥ tattha dassana ṭṭhaḥ ayam adhi paññā sikkhā
translated: The state of seeing in this context is training in the higher understanding.

original: Imā tisso sikkhāyo āvajjanto sikkhati, jānanto sikkhati, passanto sikkhati, paccavekkhanto
analyzed: imā tissaḥ sikkhāyaḥ āvajjantaḥ sikkhati jānantaḥ sikkhati passantaḥ sikkhati paccavekkhantaḥ
translated: He trains by way of adverting, he trains by way of knowing, he trains by way of seeing, he trains by way of exploring,🔽he trains by way of determining, he trains by way of faith, he trains by way of will, he trains by way of energy,

original: sikkhati, cittaṁ adhiṭṭhahanto sikkhati, saddhāya adhimuccanto sikkhati, vīriyaṁ
analyzed: sikkhati cittam adhiṭṭhahantaḥ sikkhati saddhāya adhimuccantaḥ sikkhati vīriya
translated: he trains by way of natural purity of consciousness, he trains by way of natural uprightness of understanding,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing what is the path and what is not the path,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing what is the proper and what is the improper,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of progress,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entry,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of escape,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of dispassion,

original: paggaṇhanto sikkhati, satiṁ upaṭṭhapento sikkhati, cittaṁ samādahanto sikkhati, paññāya
analyzed: paggaṇhantaḥ sikkhati satim upaṭṭhapentaḥ sikkhati cittam samādahantaḥ sikkhati paññāya
translated: he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of cessation,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of relinquishment,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of destruction,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of peace,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of higher understanding,

original: pajānanto sikkhati, abhiññeyyaṁ abhijānanto sikkhati, pariññeyyaṁ parijānanto sikkhati🔽pahātabbaṁ pajahanto sikkhati, sacchikātabbaṁ sacchikaronto sikkhati, bhāvetabbaṁ bhāvento sikkhati.
analyzed: pajānantaḥ sikkhati abhiññeyyam abhijānantaḥ sikkhati pariññeyyam parijānantaḥ sikkhati  pahātabbam pajahantaḥ sikkhati sacchikātabbam sacchikarontaḥ sikkhati bhāvetabbam bhāventaḥ sikkhati
translated: he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of enlightenment,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of the fruit,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of reviewing,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of emergence,

original: Taṁ ñātaṭṭhena ñāṇaṁ pajānanaṭṭhena paññā.🔽Tena vuccati—🔽“sutvāna saṁvare paññā sīlamaye ñāṇaṁ”.
analyzed: tam ñāta ṭṭhena ñāṇam pajānana ṭṭhena paññā  tena vuccati  sutvāna savare paññā sīla maye ñāṇa
translated: he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of rightness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of unrighteousness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,

original: Sīlamayañāṇaniddeso dutiyo.🔽1.1.3. Samādhibhāvanāmayañāṇaniddesa🔽Kathaṁ saṁvaritvā samādahane paññā samādhibhāvanāmaye ñāṇaṁ?
analyzed: sīla maya ñāṇa niddesaḥ dutiyaḥ           katham samādahane paññā samādhi bhāvanā āmaye
translated: he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,

analyzed: ekaḥ 🔽cittassa ekagga tā
translated: he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteousness,🔽he trains by way of knowing and seeing the way of entering upon a course of mixed righteousness and unrighteous

analyzed: dve samādhī
translated: There are two kinds of concentration:

analyzed: lokiyaḥ samādhi lokuttaraḥ samādhi
translated: worldly and transcendent.

analyzed: tayoḥ samādhī
translated: There are three kinds of concentration:

original: savitakkasavicāro samādhi, avitakkavicāramatto samādhi, avitakkaavicāro samādhi.
analyzed: sa vitakka sa vicāraḥ samādhi a vitakka vicāra mattaḥ samādhi a vitakka avicāraḥ samādhi
translated: with thought and examination, without thought but with examination, and without thought and without examination.

analyzed: cattāro samādhī
translated: There are four kinds of concentration:

original: hānabhāgiyo samādhi, ṭhitibhāgiyo samādhi, visesabhāgiyo samādhi, nibbedhabhāgiyo samādhi.
analyzed: hāna bhāgiyo samādhi ṭhiti bhāgiyo samādhi visesa bhāgiyo samādhi nibbedha bhāgiyo samādhi
translated: leading to diminution, leading to stagnation, leading to distinction, and leading to penetration.

analyzed: pañca samādhī
translated: There are five kinds of concentration:

analyzed: pīti pharaṇa tā sukha pharaṇa tā cetaḥ pharaṇa tā āloka pharaṇa tā paccavekkhaṇā nimitta
translated: the pervading of happiness, the pervading of bliss, the pervading of the mind, the pervading of light, and the sign of reflection.

analyzed: cha samādhī
translated: There are six kinds of concentration:

original: buddhānussativasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, dhammānussativasena cittassa
analyzed: buddha anussati vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi dhamma anussati vasena cittassa
translated: unification of mind accompanied by relishing and associated with knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the Buddha,🔽unification of mind accompanied by relishing and associated with knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the Dhamma,

original: ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, saṅghānussativasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi,
analyzed: ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi saṅgha anussati vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi
translated: unification of mind accompanied by relishing and associated with knowledge of contemplation of reflection on the Sangha,

original: sīlānussativasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, cāgānussativasena cittassa
analyzed: sīla anussati vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi cāga anussati vasena cittassa
translated: unification of mind accompanied by relishing and associated with knowledge of contemplation of reflection on virtue,🔽unification of mind accompanied by relishing and associated with knowledge of contemplation of reflection on generosity,

original: ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, devatānussativasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi.
analyzed: ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi devatā anussati vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi
translated: One-pointedness and non-distraction are concentration. One-pointedness and non-distraction of the mind by means of recollection of the gods is concentration.

analyzed: satta samādhī
translated: There are seven kinds of concentration:

original: samādhikusalatā, samādhissa samāpattikusalatā, samādhissa ṭhitikusalatā, samādhissa
analyzed: samādhi kusala tā samādhissa samāpatti kusala tā samādhissa ṭhiti kusala tā samādhissa
translated: skill in concentration, skill in attaining concentration, skill in remaining in concentration,

original: vuṭṭhānakusalatā, samādhissa kallatākusalatā, samādhissa gocarakusalatā, samādhissa abhinīhārakusalatā.
analyzed: vuṭṭhāna kusala tā samādhissa kalla tā kusala tā samādhissa gocara kusala tā samādhissa abhinīhāra kusala tā
translated: skill in emerging from concentration, skill in what is possible in concentration, skill in the range of concentration, and skill in resolution in concentration.

analyzed: aṭṭha samādhī
translated: There are eight kinds of concentration:

original: pathavīkasiṇavasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, āpokasiṇavasena …pe…🔽tejokasiṇavasena …
analyzed: pathavī kasiṇa vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepo samādhi āpo kasiṇa vasena pe  tejaḥ kasiṇa vasena
translated: one-pointedness and non-distraction of the mind by means of the earth kasiṇa is concentration, one-pointedness and non-distraction of the mind by means of the water kasiṇa …🔽by means of the fire kasiṇa …

analyzed: vāyo kasiṇa vasena  nīla kasiṇa vasena  pīta kasiṇa vasena
translated: by means of the air kasiṇa …🔽by means of the blue kasiṇa …🔽by means of the yellow kasiṇa …

analyzed: lohita kasiṇa vasena
translated: by means of the red kasiṇa …

analyzed: odāta kasiṇa vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi
translated: by means of the white kasiṇa is concentration.

original: Nava samādhī—🔽rūpāvacaro samādhi atthi hīno, atthi majjho, atthi paṇīto;
analyzed: nava samādhī  rūpāvacaraḥ samādhi atthi hīnaḥ atthi majjhaḥ atthi paṇītaḥ
translated: There are nine kinds of concentration:🔽There is a lower, a middling, and a higher kind of concentration in the form realm,

original: arūpāvacaro samādhi atthi hīno, atthi majjho, atthi paṇīto;
analyzed: arūpāvacaraḥ samādhi atthi hīnaḥ atthi majjhaḥ atthi paṇītaḥ
translated: and there is a lower, a middling, and a higher kind of concentration in the formless realm,

original: suññato samādhi, animitto samādhi, appaṇihito samādhi.
analyzed: suññataḥ samādhi animitto samādhi appaṇihitaḥ samādhi
translated: emptiness concentration, signless concentration, undirected concentration.

analyzed: dasa samādhī
translated: There are ten kinds of concentration:🔽one-pointedness of mind, non-distraction, concentration by means of the perception of a bloated corpse, …

original: uddhumātakasaññāvasena cittassa ekaggatā avikkhepo samādhi, vinīlakasaññāvasena …🔽vipubbakasaññāvasena …
analyzed: uddhumātaka saññā vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi vinīlaka saññā vasena  vipubbaka saññā vasena
translated: by means of the perception of a livid corpse, …🔽by means of the perception of a festering corpse, …

analyzed: vicchiddaka saññā vasena  vikkhāyitaka saññā vasena
translated: by means of the perception of a cut-up corpse, …🔽by means of the perception of a gnawed corpse, …

analyzed: vikkhittaka saññā vasena  hata vikkhittaka saññā vasena  lohitaka saññā vasena
translated: by means of the perception of a scattered corpse, …🔽by means of the perception of a hacked and scattered corpse, …🔽by means of the perception of a bleeding corpse, …

analyzed: puḷavaka saññā vasena
translated: by means of the perception of a worm-infested corpse, …

analyzed: aṭṭhika saññā vasena cittassa ekagga tā avikkhepaḥ samādhi
translated: by means of the perception of a skeleton, one-pointedness of mind, non-distraction, concentration.

analyzed: ime pañcapaññāsa samādhī
translated: These are the fifty-five kinds of concentration.

original: Api ca pañcavīsati samādhissa samādhiṭṭhā—🔽pariggahaṭṭhena samādhi, parivāraṭṭhena samādhi, paripūraṭṭhena samādhi, ekaggaṭṭhena
analyzed: api ca pañcavīsati samādhissa  pariggaha ṭṭhena samādhi parivāra ṭṭhena samādhi paripūra ṭṭhena samādhi ekagga ṭṭhena
translated: And there are twenty-five kinds of concentration that are bases of concentration:🔽concentration by way of embracing, concentration by way of surrounding, concentration by way of fulfilling, concentration by way of singleness,

original: samādhi, avikkhepaṭṭhena samādhi, avisāraṭṭhena samādhi, anāvilaṭṭhena samādhi, aniñjanaṭṭhena
analyzed: samādhi avikkhepa ṭṭhena samādhi avisāra ṭṭhena samādhi anāvila ṭṭhena samādhi aniñjana ṭṭhena
translated: concentration by way of non-distraction, concentration by way of non-dissipation, concentration by way of non-turbulence, concentration by way of non-greed,

analyzed: samādhi vimutta ṭṭhena samādhi ekatta upaṭṭhāna vasena cittassa ṭhita ttā samādhi sama  esati iti samādhi visamam na isati iti samādhi samam samādhi visamam  samādhi samam ādiyati iti samādhi visamam na ādiyati iti samādhi samam ādinnattā samādhi  visamam an ādinna ttā samādhi samam paṭipajjati iti samādhi visamam na paṭipajjati iti  samādhi samam paṭipanna ttā samādhi visamam na paṭipanna ttā samādhi samam jhāyati iti

analyzed: samādahane paññā samādhi bhāvanā āmaye ñāṇa
